↳ In-reply-to ¬ª Tonight has slowly become an ignore all the things online kind of night for me. Might end up taking a few days to be as offline as possible for my own sake. I'm still learning my limits, after all.

@codebalion@twtxt.prismdragon.net Take care ü§ó

↳ In-reply-to ¬ª @prologic @lucidiot @movq So, apparently yarn is transforming hashtags into search urls, ob the feed. This makes things unreadable and seems totally unnecessary. Shouldn't this be a client feature? Why should my feed have a link to a search engine instead of a hashtag? And why can't the client (when it is a visual client like goryon or the web) react to hashtags (all of them) by linking to a search interface? Am I missing something?

@marado Still I feel bad now üò¢ Anyway, here‚Äôs the PR so far‚Ä¶ Just need to work out why this test is failing and blowing up in my face ü§î https://git.mills.io/yarnsocial/go-lextwt/pulls/9

↳ In-reply-to ¬ª @prologic @lucidiot @movq So, apparently yarn is transforming hashtags into search urls, ob the feed. This makes things unreadable and seems totally unnecessary. Shouldn't this be a client feature? Why should my feed have a link to a search engine instead of a hashtag? And why can't the client (when it is a visual client like goryon or the web) react to hashtags (all of them) by linking to a search interface? Am I missing something?

@marado I‚Äôm so sorry, after poking around a fair bit, I‚Äôve realised. We intended to update the extension and remove the code/behaviour ages ago, but we just haven‚Äôt gotten around to it ü§¶‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏è ‚Äì Could I ask either @movq@www.uninformativ.de or @lyse@lyse.isobeef.org to update the spec whilst I fix this goddamn code? (PR incoming)

And why can't the client (when it is a visual client like goryon or the web) react to hashtags (all of them) by linking to a search interface? Am I missing something?

@xuu@txt.sour.is @lyse@lyse.isobeef.org help üòÖ

And why can't the client (when it is a visual client like goryon or the web) react to hashtags (all of them) by linking to a search interface? Am I missing something?

Actually‚Ä¶ I don‚Äôt get it‚Ä¶ Did we say we‚Äôd remove this shit and just didn‚Äôt do it for some stupid ass reason?! ü§¶‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏è I can‚Äôt find any evidence in any of the codebases where we‚Äôve gone and done this üò≥

Shouldn't this be a client feature? Why should my feed have a link to a search engine instead of a hashtag? And why can't the client (when it is a visual client like goryon or the web) react to hashtags (all of them) by linking to a search interface? Am I missing something?

@marado The previous Twt in this thread was written to the feed as:

2022-12-21T00:46:36Z	 @<marado https://twtxt.net/user/marado/twtxt.txt> Hold up... Rewriting #<hashtags https://twtxt.net/search?tag=hashtags> was abolished long ago... Where are you seeing this? üò≥

Which is what I expect. Whoooah wait up‚Ä¶ wtf?! üò¢ @xuu@txt.sour.is I thought we nuked this shit years ago?! ü§¶‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏è

Shouldn't this be a client feature? Why should my feed have a link to a search engine instead of a hashtag? And why can't the client (when it is a visual client like goryon or the web) react to hashtags (all of them) by linking to a search interface? Am I missing something?

@marado Hold up‚Ä¶ Rewriting #hashtags was abolished long ago‚Ä¶ Where are you seeing this? üò≥

↳ In-reply-to ¬ª @prologic is there a version of yarnd that has the toggle mentioned in this feature request? I updated to the current yarnd:dev container on octobloc.xyz for the first time since my original setup (which listed as Edge rather than 0.15.1@5f939785 like now), but it looks like it's probably not incorporated yet.

@axodys@octobloc.xyz Umm hmm haven‚Äôt built that yet üòÖ Ooops ü§¶‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏è Sorry. Do you happen to know any Go? Maybe you could help build that out? ü§î

↳ In-reply-to ¬ª I hate to be the one that instigates and continues to make true the saying "the few spoil it for the many", but off the back of this thread; I have to ask...

@justamoment @eaplmx You might. be bit right here‚Ä¶ But you have to understand the history of how this happened in the first place‚Ä¶ When I first came across Twtxt I t started out by building a ‚Äúweb‚Äù client. I called it at that time github.com/prologic/twtxt (I no longer use Github) because ‚Äúnaming is hard‚Äù. ‚Äì The project quickly picked up some interest and traction and so things kind of stuck for a while (naming wise), I‚Äôd already by this stage purchased the domain twtxt.net and hosted my ‚Äúweb‚Äù client by then‚Ä¶.

Anyway‚Ä¶ playing devil‚Äôs advocate here this is also a double-edge sword, on one hand its helped promote Twtxt itself, on the other yeah, things have gotten a it confusing (but less so as we continue to improve documentation and communications).

↳ In-reply-to ¬ª Speaking of bananas ‚Ä¶ Which one is the correct end to open them? üòè

B

content.html:
↳ In-reply-to ¬ª @prologic: Reduced refresh interval to 7200 seconds :-)

@win0err@kolesnikov.se If you‚Äôre referring to the original twtxt, then yes, it left a lot of things out and quite a bit of it is ambitious üò¢ ‚Äì It might be worthwhile one day either:

  1. rewriting the spec (which @mckinley has done a nice job of, but I still want to host that at https://dev.twtxt.net in Markdown üòÖ)
  2. start writing ‚Äúclient recommendations‚Äù (like what we did with extensions)

↳ In-reply-to ¬ª @prologic: Reduced refresh interval to 7200 seconds :-)

@win0err@kolesnikov.se Maybe you can help us with that part of the spec? ü§î It was added to honestly squelch really only one grumpy Twtxt user at the time, so we did it üòÖ But really a well behaving client will periodically fetch a feed but respect HTTP headers like Last-Modified and so the hit on a web server is minimal at best. ‚Äì And as you just found, many clients don‚Äôt yet actually even respect this field, only really yarnd does (I believe). ‚Äì And if you set it too big well then maybe nobody sees your post for a while üòÖ

I would offer documentation on our use of the WebSub protocol, however this is not possible to implement for feed authors in all cases, especially on multi-user hostrs like many of the tilde(s) I think‚Ä¶ ‚Äì Is this something we should document as an optional client feature? (I feel most feed authors probably wouldn‚Äôt care all that much)

↳ In-reply-to ¬ª @lyse It might be great if @win0err maybe cross-posted photos from pixelfeed to his twtxt feed? ü§î üôè

@lyse@lyse.isobeef.org Ahh üòÖ

↳ In-reply-to ¬ª I hate to be the one that instigates and continues to make true the saying "the few spoil it for the many", but off the back of this thread; I have to ask...

@lyse@lyse.isobeef.org Clearly I don‚Äôt know how to do footnotes ü§Ø

↳ In-reply-to ¬ª I hate to be the one that instigates and continues to make true the saying "the few spoil it for the many", but off the back of this thread; I have to ask...

@eaplmx Good points. I personally like to call Yarn.social (and have been for a while now) an ‚Äúecosystem‚Äô. I‚Äôm pretty sure it says this on the Landing Page too somewhere‚Ä¶ At some point (also) in the near future (when funds are available, because apparently its both complex and expensive to setup a not-for-profit / foundation ü§¶‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏è), there will also be a foundation (maybe be a different name?)

None of this however will have any effect on anything as long as we continue to:

  • listen to the community
  • adhere to the Twtxt specifications and Extensions
  • keep specifications and client up-to-date[^1]‚Ä®

[^1]: There is some contention over the use of Markdown in Twts (the Unicode newline literal is documented), however there is no agreement on this. It‚Äôs a bit of a tough one. Really there are some useful parts of Markdown we all like to use, and other parts that we don‚Äôt use nor need.

content.html:
↳ In-reply-to ¬ª @prologic This might be a bit of a stretch, but anyway:

Finally‚Ä¶ Even if Yarn.social and yarnd instances (Pods) tomorrow were to suddenly be spawned in the thousands, with thousands of users or more, nothing much would change I don‚Äôt think. We would have scalability problems with the search engine (pretty sure), and at that point some of those pods might be ‚ÄúHosted Pods‚Äù (for a fee), which I‚Äôm hoping by then would go back into a ‚Äúfoundation‚Äù (yet to be named, TBD) to continue to fund the ‚Äúfoundation‚Äù (TBD).

↳ In-reply-to ¬ª @prologic This might be a bit of a stretch, but anyway:

‚Ä¶ and build what I believe (and have always believed now for the past few years) the best kind of social media. The slow kind, the truly decentralised kind and the one that is easy to reason about and build against.

It‚Äôs just a freka‚Äôn text file ü§£

↳ In-reply-to ¬ª @prologic This might be a bit of a stretch, but anyway:

@movq@www.uninformativ.de I agree with @lyse@lyse.isobeef.org very well said. I guess I can also understand the ‚Äúworries‚Äù (as unfounded as they are) too, especially coming from your perspective. As you say though (thank you üôè) Yarn.social is a far cry from this situation.

All along we started out with:

What is the community doing now, what has it always done, what does it want to do.

And we formalised that.

At the same time we built what is now called yarnd, or Yarn.social Pod(s). Aside from the fact it is both decentralised and distributed and uses Twtxt, and all the Extensions, as well as IndieAuth, Atom, WebMentions and WebSub (all open source protocols and specifications, most of which are from the ‚ÄúSmall Web‚Äù) there‚Äôs nothing special going on ‚Äì yarnd is just a multi-user client and implementation of the specs.

My only goal has always been (and unlikely to change) to bring the simplicity of Twtxt to the masses (I think you all remember this). Hide the complexities of hosting a feed (as simple as that is for tech savvy folks)‚Ä¶

↳ In-reply-to ¬ª Just discovered @lucidiot's feed and am very saddened to see anyone take this position Media #Yarn.social is NOT trying to take anything over or become a "monopoly" ü§¶‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏è

@eaplmx You are right on both counts and yes I did say this and of course I still believe its true üëå That aside, calling our community and project (what should become a foundation when I have the money, with you guys driving it!) is not right though ü§ó

↳ In-reply-to ¬ª @marado well, I find that's a problem of leaving that open. Using should vs must. Leaves that to different interpretations.

@eaplmx Sadly the simple fact here is; We can debate this part of the spec until the cows come home (a silly English/Australian expression). There is just no way to agree on this at all. IMO it should be removed from the spec entirely. yarnd (as one client) for example just makes this configurable, ful-stop, with a reasonable default value that has been discussed and widely agreed upon by the community at least twice now.

↳ In-reply-to ¬ª #randomQuestionOfTheDay

No. I eat the whole thing.
